title: What Support Tickets are Chargeable / Reserving Support Time for Customers who are Entitled to it
text: It is important that we provide support for what customers are paying for. This is fair to customers who genuinely have an issue with our software or hardware and who pay us to help them, and it’s fair to K3 that we are not spending time doing work which customers are not paying for (which also means we’re not spending enough time helping customers who are paying for something!). The first part below is mainly for people answering up the phones, but at least the second part applies to anyone working on a support ticket. 1. First, the obvious for people picking up the hotline If a customer calls and wants help with anything which is not related to our software or hardware, then we should not help them because they’re actually stopping us helping customers who genuinely have a problem with what we are contracted to provide.. Examples include if their internet is not working, or they want help with another program installed on their computer/terminal. Believe it or not, this does happen, so don’t be afraid to… Politely explain to them that we can only spend time helping them with issues with our hardware or software. If they ask why – you can give the reason above that we have other customers who are waiting for us to help with our products, and of course, they are not paying for us to be their general IT help (nor do we offer that service!). You could suggest they Google the issue or find their actual supplier/team who should be helping them. Log the call anyway (and resolve as “Not Supported by K3”) so that we can track persistent offenders! If a customer questions something's chargeable, or what's included in their annual fees, you can refer them to What will the Support team help me with? which also includes a link to the full SLA 2. Secondly, the less obvious, but in the same spirit as the above: If you find that you’re doing/are asked to do some work for a customer which is specific to them (perhaps a change to an integration or a question on their config), then stop and think if it should be chargeable. If the customer just needs our help with how to do something, this is theoretically not included in their annual fees (which is for investigating and resolving faults with our products/hardware), so guidelines are: A maximum of 15 minutes should be spent on helping customers with how to do something or any other non-K3 faults. After this, refer the customer to product documentation or a CSM as per Consider how busy you/we are with other tickets for things which are genuine faults. You may need to come back to the how-to customer later. There may be the odd exception where you need to go over the 15 minutes, but this should be an exception, and if this happens regularly for the same customer, then definitely refer to the CSM. If the customer does something to the system which breaks things (e.g. they delete their database, have a virus attack, have a new email server we need to change configuration to work with), then this is chargeable work If the customer needs training or consultancy (or if you're not sure) then contact the relevant Customer Success Manager to ask them (also see Passing Sales Opportunities to CSMs). If you can’t get hold of them, then feel free to reach out to a Support Manager. If it should be chargeable, then the Customer Success Manager will communicate with the customer. For more information on Support Rates and a workflow on when/how to apply them, please see Support Effort Rates / Price List - What and When Also see General Guide to Identifying & Booking Chargeable Work involving Support
description:
It is important that we provide support for what customers are paying for. This is fair to customers who genuinely have an issue with our software or hardware and who pay us to help them, and it’s fair to K3 that we are not spending time doing work which customers are not paying for (which also means we’re not spending enough time helping customers who are paying for something!).

 

The first part below is mainly for people answering up the phones, but at least the second part applies to anyone working on a support ticket.

 

1. First, the obvious for people picking up the hotline

  • If a customer calls and wants help with anything which is not related to our software or hardware, then we should not help them because they’re actually stopping us helping customers who genuinely have a problem with what we are contracted to provide..
    • Examples include if their internet is not working, or they want help with another program installed on their computer/terminal.
    • Believe it or not, this does happen, so don’t be afraid to…
  • Politely explain to them that we can only spend time helping them with issues with our hardware or software.
    • If they ask why – you can give the reason above that we have other customers who are waiting for us to help with our products, and of course, they are not paying for us to be their general IT help (nor do we offer that service!). You could suggest they Google the issue or find their actual supplier/team who should be helping them.
    • Log the call anyway (and resolve as “Not Supported by K3”) so that we can track persistent offenders!


If a customer questions something's chargeable, or what's included in their annual fees, you can refer them to What will the Support team help me with? which also includes a link to the full SLA


2. Secondly, the less obvious, but in the same spirit as the above:

  • If you find that you’re doing/are asked to do some work for a customer which is specific to them (perhaps a change to an integration or a question on their config), then stop and think if it should be chargeable.
  • If the customer just needs our help with how to do something, this is theoretically not included in their annual fees (which is for investigating and resolving faults with our products/hardware), so guidelines are:
    • A maximum of 15 minutes should be spent on helping customers with how to do something or any other non-K3 faults. After this, refer the customer to product documentation or a CSM as per 
    • Consider how busy you/we are with other tickets for things which are genuine faults. You may need to come back to the how-to customer later.
    • There may be the odd exception where you need to go over the 15 minutes, but this should be an exception, and if this happens regularly for the same customer, then definitely refer to the CSM.
  • If the customer does something to the system which breaks things (e.g. they delete their database, have a virus attack, have a new email server we need to change configuration to work with), then this is chargeable work
  • If the customer needs training or consultancy (or if you're not sure) then contact the relevant Customer Success Manager to ask them (also see Passing Sales Opportunities to CSMs).
    • If you can’t get hold of them, then feel free to reach out to a Support Manager.
    • If it should be chargeable, then the Customer Success Manager will communicate with the customer. 


For more information on Support Rates and a workflow on when/how to apply them, please see Support Effort Rates / Price List - What and When

Also see General Guide to Identifying & Booking Chargeable Work involving Support

title: General Guide to Identifying & Booking Chargeable Work involving Support
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Step 1: Is the ticket chargeable? Step 2: What to do if it might be chargeable? Step 3: How to quote the correct rate? Step 4: How to make sure the correct amount is invoiced 4a. Track Time Spent 4b. Get an Opportunity into CRM 4c. Update the CRM info into Freshdesk 4d. Update Customer Success when the work is completed This general guide is for the Support team and CSMs to make the overall process clear, and link to the relevant detailed articles on how to do things This process is intended for small amounts of chargeable support effort, not for larger training and project work which should be referred to CSMs in the normal way Step 1: Is the ticket chargeable? See What Support Tickets are Chargeable / Reserving Support Time for Customers who are Entitled to it Step 2: What to do if it might be chargeable? See What to do if you think a customer has asked you to do some work which should be chargeable Key Principle: if it is going to take more than 15 minutes to resolve, and you're not 100% sure it's a fault with K3 software/code or supported hardware: - Tell the customer it is/may be chargeable - Get their agreement in writing that they will pay if it turns out to not be a K3 fault Step 3: How to quote the correct effort and rate? Effort/Time Estimate the effort to the nearest half an hour. We should not quote less than half an hour for chargeable support work (projects have a higher minimum of one hour, but small support effort work has a lower admin overhead and no project management). Be conservative (round up, not down), and make it clear that it's an estimate based on the best of your current understanding of what's required. It's Time and Materials, so it could take less or more time. Rate See Support Effort Rates / Price List - What and When which includes and a decision workflow to help you select the correct rate. The correct codes should always be used, but CSMs (not Support) can apply a discount or an uplift according to what has been agreed/charged to the customer before (but inflation must always be added from the previous calendar year) Key Principle: If the opportunity/request has come through a Support ticket, then quote the relevant Support rate If a customer is needing chargeable support effort on a regular basis, please refer to a Support Manager who can then discuss with the customer and CSM if an annual amount of hours at a discounted rate should be offered. Step 4: How to make sure the correct amount is invoiced 4a. Track Time Spent See How to keep track of your time on chargeable tickets 4b. Get an Opportunity into CRM Having an opportunity in CRM ensures that the work will be in sales reports and is invoiced. Are the estimated number of hours over 4? YES If the estimated hours are over 4, set the FD ticket to status "Passed to Customer Success Manager" and do not do any work until you have confirmation that a signed order has been received No For everyone (except The Netherlands) If the estimated hours are 4 or less, you just need the customer to confirm on the ticket that they will pay at the quoted rate (see How to Choose the Correct Rate ) before going ahead with the work For The Netherlands onlyThe Netherlands team have a semi-automated process which was implemented when they were using CRM for support tickets which applies to tickets where up to 4 hours has been spent: NL How to book chargeable work from Freshdesk to CRM . This creates an Opportunity and an Order, but for everyone else, the minimum requirement is only to add an Opportunity. Regardless of whether the effort is over or under 4 hours, via a Thread on the ticket, send details of the work to: DE: Anita Suwala DK: Dustin Christensen UK: Ashleigh Duckett The CSM team member will enter an Opportunity into CRM with "FD" and the ticket number at the beginning of the title (see example below) 4c. Update the CRM info into Freshdesk To ensure that nothing is missed, and that we can reconcile chargeable tickets from Freshdesk with CRM, enter the CRM Opportunity Number into the Freshdesk ticket. Key Principle: Whoever enters the Opportunity into CRM, make sure that the Opp Number is added to the Freshdesk ticket which will mean the CSM team member telling Support on the ticket Thread OR updating the ticket directly if they have the relevant permissions 4d. Update Customer Success when the work is completed Once Support has completed the work: Message the CSM team member and local Finance team member on the ticket Thread to confirm the work is done and how many hours you've spent (make sure it matches up to the amount logged on the ticket!) Resolve the ticket as usual
description:
TABLE OF CONTENTS

  • Step 1: Is the ticket chargeable?
  • Step 2: What to do if it might be chargeable?
  • Step 3: How to quote the correct rate?
  • Step 4: How to make sure the correct amount is invoiced
    • 4a. Track Time Spent
    • 4b. Get an Opportunity into CRM
    • 4c. Update the CRM info into Freshdesk 
    • 4d. Update Customer Success when the work is completed


This general guide is for the Support team and CSMs to make the overall process clear, and link to the relevant detailed articles on how to do things

 

This process is intended for small amounts of chargeable support effort, not for larger training and project work which should be referred to CSMs in the normal way



Step 1: Is the ticket chargeable?

See What Support Tickets are Chargeable / Reserving Support Time for Customers who are Entitled to it 


Step 2: What to do if it might be chargeable?

See What to do if you think a customer has asked you to do some work which should be chargeable

 

Key Principle: if it is going to take more than 15 minutes to resolve, and you're not 100% sure it's a fault with K3 software/code or supported hardware:
- Tell the customer it is/may be chargeable
- Get their agreement in writing that they will pay if it turns out to not be a K3 fault


Step 3: How to quote the correct effort and rate?

Effort/Time

Estimate the effort to the nearest half an hour. We should not quote less than half an hour for chargeable support work (projects have a higher minimum of one hour, but small support effort work has a lower admin overhead and no project management).


Be conservative (round up, not down), and make it clear that it's an estimate based on the best of your current understanding of what's required. It's Time and Materials, so it could take less or more time.


Rate

See Support Effort Rates / Price List - What and When  which includes and a decision workflow to help you select the correct rate.  The correct codes should always be used, but CSMs (not Support) can apply a discount or an uplift according to what has been agreed/charged to the customer before (but inflation must always be added from the previous calendar year)


Key Principle: If the opportunity/request has come through a Support ticket, then quote the relevant Support rate


If a customer is needing chargeable support effort on a regular basis, please refer to a Support Manager who can then discuss with the customer and CSM if an annual amount of hours at a discounted rate should be offered.


Step 4: How to make sure the correct amount is invoiced

4a. Track Time Spent

See How to keep track of your time on chargeable tickets 


4b. Get an Opportunity into CRM

Having an opportunity in CRM ensures that the work will be in sales reports and is invoiced.


  1. Are the estimated number of hours over 4?
    YES If the estimated hours are over 4, set the FD ticket to status "Passed to Customer Success Manager" and do not do any work until you have confirmation that a signed order has been received

    No 
    For everyone (except The Netherlands)
    If the estimated hours are 4 or less, you just need the customer to confirm on the ticket that they will pay at the quoted rate (see How to Choose the Correct Rate ) before going ahead with the work

    For The Netherlands onlyThe Netherlands team have a semi-automated process which was implemented when they were using CRM for support tickets which applies to tickets where up to 4 hours has been spent:  NL How to book chargeable work from Freshdesk to CRM . This creates an Opportunity and an Order, but for everyone else, the minimum requirement is only to add an Opportunity.

  2. Regardless of whether the effort is over or under 4 hours, via a Thread on the ticket, send details of the work to:
    DE: Anita Suwala
    DK: Dustin Christensen
    UK: Ashleigh Duckett

  3. The CSM team member will enter an Opportunity into CRM with "FD" and the ticket number at the beginning of the title (see example below)



4c. Update the CRM info into Freshdesk 

To ensure that nothing is missed, and that we can reconcile chargeable tickets from Freshdesk with CRM, enter the CRM Opportunity Number into the Freshdesk ticket.



Key Principle: Whoever enters the Opportunity into CRM, make sure that the Opp Number is added to the Freshdesk ticket which will mean the CSM team member telling Support on the ticket Thread OR updating the ticket directly if they have the relevant permissions



4d. Update Customer Success when the work is completed

Once Support has completed the work:

  1. Message the CSM team member and local Finance team member on the ticket Thread to confirm the work is done and how many hours you've spent (make sure it matches up to the amount logged on the ticket!)
  2. Resolve the ticket as usual

title: Support Effort Rates / Price List - What and When
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS TABLE OF CONTENTS What to do if you think a customer has asked you to do some work which should be chargeable March 2025 - March 2026 Price List How to Choose the Correct Rate Also See... What to do if you think a customer has asked you to do some work which should be chargeable For guidance on what is chargeable, please see What Support Tickets are Chargeable / Reserving Support Time for Customers who are Entitled to it If you are asked to do some work on a ticket by a customer which you think is chargeable and may take more than 4 hours, you should pass the request on to the appropriate Customer Success Manager with an estimate of the amount of time you will need (if relevant). The exceptions to the above are: 1. The Netherlands team are permitted to raise their own work orders in CRM if the effort required is 4 hours or less and the customer has confirmed in writing that they will pay (see NL How to book chargeable work from Freshdesk to CRM 2. If the customer is just asking a question which you think will take less than 15 minutes to answer, but while answering their question it becomes clear that 15 minutes is not enough, you need to stop and tell the customer they need to place a work order. If for any reason it's not possible to refer to a CSM when you need to (e.g. it’s an urgent request on a weekend) then you can quote the customer from the price list below and go ahead and do the work only if the customer confirms in writing that they will pay the rate and for the estimated number of hours you think the work will take Prices below are excluding local tax and parts (if applicable; they will be added when invoiced) If you use all the hours up that you estimated and there is more to do, then you will need the customer to confirm in writing again that they will pay for the estimated extra Once the work is complete, you will need to message the CSM and local Finance team member through a Thread on the Freshdesk ticket with details of what you've done, and the total hours so that they can raise the order to invoice the customer (exception for NL team <4 hours as above). March 2025 - March 2026 Price List This price list is in the Microsoft CRM system (Product Group SV-SUPPORT) which is where the CSMs can view it, but Support do not generally have access to this information, so it is copied below. In the scenario given earlier where a customer asks you to do something urgently and you have their permission in writing, then you will most likely be choosing the relevant "Emergency" rate Remember that tax is not included below which is for time/effort only CRM Product ID CRM Product (description of the rate) GBP EUR DKK NOK SEK REMOTE SUPPORT P0000585 Support Remote Consulting - Advance Purchase -Normal Hours 112 129 1181 1775 1838 P0000586 Support Remote Consulting - Advance Purchase -Extended Hours 169 194 1470 2205 2284 P0000588 Support Remote Consulting - Emergency -Normal Hours 150 172 1654 2484 2573 P0000589 Support Remote Consulting - Emergency -Extended Hours 225 258 1890 2930 3035 ON-SITE SUPPORT P0000591 Support On-Site Consulting - Advance Purchase -Normal Hours 133 153 1536 2307 2389 P0000592 Support On-Site Consulting - Advance Purchase -Extended Hours 200 229 1772 2662 2693 P0000594 Support On-Site Consulting - Emergency -Normal Hours 179 205 1949 2928 2410 P0000595 Support On-Site Consulting - Emergency -Extended Hours 267 307 2067 3106 3602 HARDWARE REMOTE AND ON-SITE SUPPORT P0000579 Hardware Support - Remote Services 97 111 840 1260 1307 P0000580 Hardware Support - Remote Services -Extended Hours 146 168 1271 1906 1974 P0000582 Hardware Support - On-Site Services 112 129 977 1465 1517 P0000583 Hardware Support - On-Site Services -Extended Hours 169 194 1470 2205 2284 How to Choose the Correct Rate The below flowchart can be followed to make sure you choose the correct rate (and which team will do the work) Click the below to open up a PDF which you can zoom into and click on the links in it where applicable Source: Chargeable Support Effort Rate Decision Workflow.vsdx Also See... General Guide to Identifying & Booking Chargeable Work involving Support What will the Support team help me with? How to keep track of your time on chargeable tickets
description:
TABLE OF CONTENTS

  • TABLE OF CONTENTS
    • What to do if you think a customer has asked you to do some work which should be chargeable
    • March 2025 - March 2026 Price List
    • How to Choose the Correct Rate
    • Also See...


What to do if you think a customer has asked you to do some work which should be chargeable

For guidance on what is chargeable, please see What Support Tickets are Chargeable / Reserving Support Time for Customers who are Entitled to it


If you are asked to do some work on a ticket by a customer which you think is chargeable and may take more than 4 hours, you should pass the request on to the appropriate Customer Success Manager with an estimate of the amount of time you will need (if relevant).


The exceptions to the above are:
1. The Netherlands team are permitted to raise their own work orders in CRM if the effort required is 4 hours or less and the customer has confirmed in writing that they will pay (see NL How to book chargeable work from Freshdesk to CRM
2. If the customer is just asking a question which you think will take less than 15 minutes to answer, but while answering their question it becomes clear that 15 minutes is not enough, you need to stop and tell the customer they need to place a work order.


If for any reason it's not possible to refer to a CSM when you need to (e.g. it’s an urgent request on a weekend) then you can quote the customer from the price list below and go ahead and do the work only if the customer confirms in writing that they will pay the rate and for the estimated number of hours you think the work will take

  • Prices below are excluding local tax and parts (if applicable; they will be added when invoiced)
  • If you use all the hours up that you estimated and there is more to do, then you will need the customer to confirm in writing again that they will pay for the estimated extra 
  • Once the work is complete, you will need to message the CSM and local Finance team member through a Thread on the Freshdesk ticket with details of what you've done, and the total hours so that they can raise the order to invoice the customer (exception for NL team <4 hours as above).


March 2025 - March 2026 Price List

  • This price list is in the Microsoft CRM system (Product Group SV-SUPPORT) which is where the CSMs can view it, but Support do not generally have access to this information, so it is copied below. 
  • In the scenario given earlier where a customer asks you to do something urgently and you have their permission in writing, then you will most likely be choosing the relevant "Emergency" rate


Remember that tax is not included below which is for time/effort only

How to Choose the Correct Rate

The below flowchart can be followed to make sure you choose the correct rate (and which team will do the work)

title: How to keep track of your time on chargeable tickets
text: If you're working on a ticket which you think may be chargeable, you should not spend more than 15 minutes on it without the customer agreeing to pay for your time as per What Support Tickets are Chargeable / Reserving Support Time for Customers who are Entitled to it If you have been authorised to spend more than 15 minutes on a non-fault ticket (by the customer agreeing to pay or by a support manager), then add your time to the ticket (including the 15 minutes already spent) using the Log Time functionality (panel on every ticket). You can add multiple time entries as you continue to work on the ticket. Always log the exact time you spent, even if it's less than a minimum order value for example (management and/or Finance can make sure the invoice is correct) On the ticket, in the Time Logs panel, you will be able to see each entry and the total time which you can then use to update the customer and the CSM to make sure the correct amount of time is invoiced.
description:
If you're working on a ticket which you think may be chargeable, you should not spend more than 15 minutes on it without the customer agreeing to pay for your time as per What Support Tickets are Chargeable / Reserving Support Time for Customers who are Entitled to it 


If you have been authorised to spend more than 15 minutes on a non-fault ticket (by the customer agreeing to pay or by a support manager), then add your time to the ticket (including the 15 minutes already spent) using the Log Time functionality (panel on every ticket). You can add multiple time entries as you continue to work on the ticket.


Always log the exact time you spent, even if it's less than a minimum order value for example (management and/or Finance can make sure the invoice is correct)





On the ticket, in the Time Logs panel, you will be able to see each entry and the total time which you can then use to update the customer and the CSM to make sure the correct amount of time is invoiced.

title: NL How to book chargeable work from Freshdesk to CRM
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Introduction Agreements (Office Waalwijk) What to do if you think a customer has asked you to do some work which should be chargeable In case of A chargeable work is over 4 hours : In case of B chargeable work is under 4 hours : Manual for booking chargeable work under 4 hours Introduction This is a temporary process for The Netherlands team to facilitate entering orders quickly. We will use the CRM Case to Order for this which was set up when the Support team were using CRM as it's ticketing system. Agreements (Office Waalwijk) In the Waalwijk Office we have made agreements with the sales department in order to handle chargeable work easier and faster. It is therefore not certain that this procedure also applies to the other offices. What to do if you think a customer has asked you to do some work which should be chargeable For guidance on what is chargeable, please see What Support Tickets are Chargeable / Reserving Support Time for Customers who are Entitled to it As is described on Support Effort Rates / Price List - What and When : If the chargeable work is over 4 hours we tell the customer that for this ticket an Order will be made and pass the ticket to the CSM. If the chargeable work is under 4 hours we don’t need the CSM but ask the approval of the customer and let customer confirm on the ticket, then carry out the work according to its priority and if its an emergency (higher rate) or not. In case of A chargeable work is over 4 hours : The CSM will make an opportunity in CRM, ask customer to sign and make an Order for the work. The planner will plan the activities for a support employee. In case of B chargeable work is under 4 hours : In short it comes down to the following (see detailed manual below): After resolving the FD ticket Make a new case in CRM with FD+ticketnumber and short description as Case title Add billing consumables Resolve the case. An automatic Order is made Go to the Sales / Orders Change the Name and Price List Item Click the next stage (Delivery) Make a private not in FD with the Orderr. Manual for booking chargeable work under 4 hours Approval of customer Resolving the FD ticket Make a new case in CRM with FD+ticketnumber and short description as Case title Add billing consumables, choose the correct item. See for correct CRM Product ID: Support Effort Rates / Price List - What and When Save and Resolve the case. An automatic Order is made. This can take some minutes. Go to the Sales / Orders Choose your Order. It will be on top of your standard view. Change the Name and Price List Item with FD - Check if the correct Price List is used. Otherwise change it. Click Save Click Next stage (Delivery) and Save&Close DO NOT CLICK on Finish !! State of order is now Invoiced and ready to be handled by the Finance team. Make a private note in FD with the CRM Order nr. and link Ready
description:
TABLE OF CONTENTS

  • Introduction
  • Agreements (Office Waalwijk)
  • What to do if you think a customer has asked you to do some work which should be chargeable
    • In case of A chargeable work is over 4 hours :
    • In case of B chargeable work is under 4 hours :  
  • Manual for booking chargeable work under 4 hours


Introduction

 

This is a temporary process for The Netherlands team to facilitate entering orders quickly. We will use the CRM Case to Order for this which was set up when the Support team were using CRM as it's ticketing system.


Agreements (Office Waalwijk)

In the Waalwijk Office we have made agreements with the sales department in order to handle chargeable work easier and faster.

It is therefore not certain that this procedure also applies to the other offices.


What to do if you think a customer has asked you to do some work which should be chargeable

For guidance on what is chargeable, please see What Support Tickets are Chargeable / Reserving Support Time for Customers who are Entitled to it


As is described on Support Effort Rates / Price List - What and When :

 

  1. If the chargeable work is over 4 hours we tell the customer that for this ticket an Order will be made and pass the ticket to the CSM.
  1. If the chargeable work is under 4 hours we don’t need the CSM but ask the approval of the customer and let customer confirm on the ticket, then carry out the work according to its priority and if its an emergency (higher rate) or not.

In case of A chargeable work is over 4 hours :

The CSM will make an opportunity in CRM, ask customer to sign and make an Order for the work. The planner will plan the activities for a support employee.

 

In case of B chargeable work is under 4 hours :  

In short it comes down to the following (see detailed manual below):

  • After resolving the FD ticket
  • Make a new case in CRM with FD+ticketnumber and short description as Case title
  • Add billing consumables
  • Resolve the case. An automatic Order is made
  • Go to the Sales / Orders
  • Change the Name and Price List Item
  • Click the next stage (Delivery)
  • Make a private not in FD with the Orderr.

  

Manual for booking chargeable work under 4 hours

  • Approval of customer

 

 

  • Resolving the FD ticket

 

  • Make a new case in CRM with FD+ticketnumber and short description as Case title

 

  • Add billing consumables, choose the correct item.

 

See for correct CRM Product ID: Support Effort Rates / Price List - What and When 



 

  • Save and Resolve the case. 

 

An automatic Order is made. This can take some minutes.

 

  • Go to the Sales / Orders

 

Choose your Order. It will be on top of your standard view.

 

 

  

Change the Name and Price List Item with FD<nr> - <Description>

        


 

Check if the correct Price List is used. Otherwise change it.

Click Save

 

  • Click Next stage (Delivery) and Save&Close   DO NOT CLICK on Finish !!

               

 

 

State of order is now Invoiced and ready to be handled by the Finance team.

 

  • Make a private note in FD with the CRM Order nr. and link

Ready

title: Fixing MStore customer database performance issues
text: We regularly have customers with database performance issues which are caused by them not maintaining their own database (or even server) properly. This means that we end up defragmenting, reindexing their database, checking server memory etc which is not a service we should be performing free of charge, especially when we offer hosting to take that pain away from customers if they don’t want (or have the knowledge) to manage their MStore database themselves. We therefore have the offering published in K3 MStore Database Optimisation and Maintenance Plan – please familiarise yourself with it. There is a behind the scenes technical schedule for what we would do if a customer signs up to the plan. If a customer has a serious trading issue which you think is caused by the database needing maintenance, we will undertake performance optimising tasks, BUT free of charge once per year only (assuming they don’t have the annual Optimisation and Maintenance Plan). If they do not have any tickets in the last 12 months with the tag “DB Maintenance”, then go ahead and do the necessary database maintenance task(s) to resolve the issue. Do not set up any regular tasks, just run whatever one-off job(s) you need to resolve the incident. Tag the ticket with the existing tag “DB Maintenance” so that we can track their annual usage. Send the canned response MStore DB Slow Performance - Fixed One Off. If they do have any tickets in the last 12 months with the tag (I added this tag today, so there won’t be any yet), use the canned response MStore DB Slow Performance - Trading - Won't Fix . If a customer has reporting performance issues which you think is caused by the database needing maintenance, we will NOT do any database maintenance for them free of charge. Please send them canned response MStore DB Slow Performance - Reporting - Won't Fix I’ve set up the three canned responses up so that you don’t have to worry about how to word anything to the customer, and so that we give customers a consistent story. Screenshots of them are below (the titles are not shown to the customer!)
description:
We regularly have customers with database performance issues which are caused by them not maintaining their own database (or even server) properly. This means that we end up defragmenting, reindexing their database, checking server memory etc which is not a service we should be performing free of charge, especially when we offer hosting to take that pain away from customers if they don’t want (or have the knowledge) to manage their MStore database themselves.

 

We therefore have the offering published in K3 MStore Database Optimisation and Maintenance Plan – please familiarise yourself with it. There is a behind the scenes technical schedule for what we would do if a customer signs up to the plan. 


If a customer has a serious trading issue which you think is caused by the database needing maintenance, we will undertake performance optimising tasks, BUT free of charge once per year only (assuming they don’t have the annual Optimisation and Maintenance Plan).

  • If they do not have any tickets in the last 12 months with the tag “DB Maintenance”, then go ahead and do the necessary database maintenance task(s) to resolve the issue.
    • Do not set up any regular tasks, just run whatever one-off job(s) you need to resolve the incident.
    • Tag the ticket with the existing tag “DB Maintenance” so that we can track their annual usage.
    • Send the canned response MStore DB Slow Performance - Fixed One Off.
  • If they do have any tickets in the last 12 months with the tag (I added this tag today, so there won’t be any yet), use the canned response MStore DB Slow Performance - Trading - Won't Fix .

 

 

If a customer has reporting performance issues which you think is caused by the database needing maintenance, we will NOT do any database maintenance for them free of charge.

  • Please send them canned response MStore DB Slow Performance - Reporting - Won't Fix

 

 

I’ve set up the three canned responses up so that you don’t have to worry about how to word anything to the customer, and so that we give customers a consistent story. Screenshots of them are below (the titles are not shown to the customer!)
